entry.content:
GayadÄsaâ€™s NyÄyacandrikÄ is one of the important early commentaries on the SuÅ›rutasaá¹ƒhitÄ that has largely been lost in the sands of time. I say â€œlargelyâ€ because only a relatively small portion is known to have survived: the commentary on one of SuÅ›rutaâ€™s six books, the NidÄnasthÄna, which was edited and published by Acharya Trivikramji in his 1938 edition of the SuÅ›rutasaá¹ƒhitÄ (Ä€cÄrya & Ä€cÄrya, 1938).

We know that GayadÄsaâ€™s commentary was important because it was frequently cited by á¸Œalhaá¹‡a, a twelfth-century author whose commentary came to define the version of the SuÅ›rutasaá¹ƒhitÄ that was printed and widely disseminated in the twentieth century. Since á¸Œalhaá¹‡a often refers to GayadÄsaâ€™s views and records many variant readings known to this earlier commentator, it is clear that GayadÄsa played a significant role in the transmission and interpretation of the SuÅ›rutasaá¹ƒhitÄ.

Given GayadÄsaâ€™s importance to the history of SuÅ›rutasaá¹ƒhitÄ, the existence of several unpublished manuscripts of the NyÄyacandrikÄ should be a priority for further research on the history of this medical tradition. For this reason, I was delighted to have the opportunity to read and transcribe GayadÄsaâ€™s commentary on the second chapter of SuÅ›rutaâ€™s SÅ«trasthÄna.

My delight soon turned to anguish when I examined manuscript Bikaner Anup 4389, which is held by the Anup Sanskrit Library in the Lalgarh Palace, Bikaner. The most obvious problem was the frequent lacunae in the text, which the scribe represented with a dash for each syllable that was missing. It appears that the manuscript from which the scribe was copying had already been severely damaged, because several lines of dashes, sometimes numbering up to ten or twelve, appear on every folio. Each lacuna renders sentences, compounds, and words incomplete.

Perhaps even more devastating than the lacunae, however, was the amount of gibberish spread throughout the text. Scholars who work with handwritten manuscripts of texts that have been poorly transmitted expect to encounter mistakes, and if these errors are small, they can usually be corrected so that the text can be understand, if not fully, then at least substantially. For editing purposes, one typically requires two or more manuscripts to correct a range of mistakes with some confidence.

Unfortunately, manuscript Anup 4389 contains mistakes in every sentence, some of which a later hand has attempted to correct. Many letters have been crossed out and replaced with others written in the margin or above the line. These attempted corrections sometimes render the text even more illegible. When combined with the lacunae, the gibberish makes much of the manuscript incomprehensible. The difficulty of reading this manuscript (without another copy for comparison) is particularly evident in passages that correspond to á¸Œalhaá¹‡aâ€™s commentary. In such instances, one can be more certain of what GayadÄsa originally wrote and therefore see the manuscriptâ€™s gibberish clearly. For example,

á¸Œalhaá¹‡a: krodhaá¸¥ parasyÄpakÄrapÅ«rvakaá¹ƒ há¹›dayottejaá¸¥
GayadÄsa: kovaá¸¥ parasyatyakÄrapÅ«rvikÄ haravitejaá¸¥

In some cases, the manuscript reading is good enough to make sense of the text when read against á¸Œalhaá¹‡aâ€™s parallel comment:

á¸Œalhaá¹‡a: kÄmaá¸¥ viÅ›iá¹£á¹­astrÄ«viá¹£ayasparÅ›asaá¹…kalpaá¸¥, athavÄ Å›abdÄdiá¹£u grahaá¹‡apravá¹›ttirvÄ, svabÄndhavaká¹›tasneho vÄ kÄmaá¸¥

GayadÄsa: tatra kÄmo vi+á¹£á¹­astriviá¹£ayasparÅ›aá¸¥ prakalpaá¸¥ athavÄ Å›abdÄdiá¹£u grahapratahir vÄ kÄmo diá¹£va grahapravá¹›ttisu vidyÄkÅ«laá¹ƒ

In other cases, however, the text is so corrupt that one cannot be certain that the passages are parallel:

á¸Œalhaá¹‡a: lobhaá¸¥ parasvagrahaá¹‡ecchÄ; GayadÄsa: lÄtetharadhagrahÄ

I did not record the number of parallel passages between GayadÄsa and á¸Œalhaá¹‡aâ€™s commentaries in the section I transcribed (and it would likely be more productive to do so with sections of the NidÄnasthÄna) but I was left with the impression that at least 20% of GayadÄsaâ€™s commentary was close to á¸Œalhaá¹‡aâ€™s. This suggests that á¸Œalhaá¹‡a tacitly borrowed material from GayadÄsa, in addition to the passages he explicitly attributed to him. In certain places, GayadÄsaâ€™s commentary is more extensive, and á¸Œalhaá¹‡a seems to be summarising it. And in other places, á¸Œalhaá¹‡a expands on it.

Although manuscript Anup 4389 is unlikely to ever serve as the sole basis for a critical edition and translation, it may be possible (albeit frustrating) to use it to identify parallels with á¸Œalhaá¹‡a. Such parallels may help to elucidate the extent to which this later commentator, whose work may appear largely original, was in fact redacting material from his predecessors.

entry.title: Text Emendation - Dwellers in the Sea

link.title: Text Emendation - Dwellers in the Sea

entry.content:
Introduction (Dominik Wujastyk)

The following post illustrates the creative philological process that can lead to an emendation to a text in spite of the transmitted readings of the manuscript witnesses.

During an online reading seminar, we were puzzled by the Nepalese manuscript readings of passage SS 3.1.3. In the vulgate version, the passage reads (Ä€cÄrya & Ä€cÄrya, 1938, p. 338):

tad ekam anekeá¹£Äá¹ƒ ká¹£etrajÃ±ÄnÄm adhiá¹£á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ samudra ivaudakanÄá¹ƒ bhÄvÄnÄm Â 

That One is the foundation of the many Witnesses, just like the ocean for aquatic (audaka) beings.

The Nepalese witnesses N and H both read ivodakaujasÄá¹ƒ â€œfor beings who have water as their energy (ojas).â€ This is an unusual use of the word ojas and the meaning of the simile is not clear.

Philipp Maas, project collaborator (ORCID), was able to suggest a compelling solution to this conundrum.

Reflections (Philipp Maas)

Following our online meeting, the illustration in ÅšÄ 1.3 continued to puzzle me. Even if the phrase tad ekam anekeá¹£Äá¹ƒ ká¹£etrajÃ±ÄnÄm adhiá¹£á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ samudra ivodakaujasÄá¹ƒ bhÄvÄnÄm makes some sense, it is hardly correct because the technical term -ojas as a final part of a bahuvrÄ«hi compound does not fit the context. It remains unclear what kind of entities or beings could be described as â€œhaving water as their powerâ€ and how such a characterisation can be understood in a comparison (which should be clear without specialist knowledge) of the role of avyakta for the ká¹£etrejÃ±as.

In this situation, an editor could either mark the edited text as corrupt or suggest an emendation. However, my suggestion to read ivodakajÄnÄá¹ƒ instead of ivodakaujasÄá¹ƒ was unsatisfactory because there is no reason why the unobjectionable and easy reading ivodakajÄnÄá¹ƒ could be changed in the course of the transmission into the more difficult but apparently incorrect ivodakaujasÄá¹ƒ in the Nepalese version. I have now found a better solution to this problem and propose a different emendation, namely to emend udakaujasÄá¹ƒ to udakaukasÄá¹ƒ â€œhaving water as their house or habitat, living in water, aquatic,â€ which involves the change of the single aká¹£ara ja to ka, making okas out of ojas.

Admittedly, I have not yet been able to detect an occurrence of the word udakaukas in Sanskrit literature, but jalaukas is quite common, meaning â€œleechâ€ or â€œaquatic beingâ€ as, for example, in MBh 12.195.22: Å›ubhÄÅ›ubhaá¹ƒ karma ká¹›taá¹ƒ yad asya tad eva pratyÄdadate svadehe / mano â€˜nuvartanti parÄvarÄá¹‡i jalaukasaá¸¥ srota ivÄnukÅ«lam // (22.2). Since jalaukas is a substantivised adjective, nothing prevents the usage of the parallel formation udakaukas as a bahuvrÄ«hi meaning â€œaquatic.â€

The passage

tad ekam anekeá¹£Äá¹ƒ ká¹£etrajÃ±ÄnÄm adhiá¹£á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ samudra ivodakaukasÄá¹ƒ bhÄvÄnÄm Â 

would then translate as

This is the single abode of the multiple Selves (â€œknowers of the fieldâ€) like the ocean for aquatic beings.

Emending the text from ivodakaujasÄá¹ƒ bhÄvÄnÄm to ivodakaukasÄá¹ƒ bhÄvÄnÄm satisfies both requirements of emendations.

  • First, the emendation resolves the issue of meaning. The dá¹›á¹£á¹­Änta compares the single avyakta in which multiple Selves lead their existences with the single ocean, in which multiple aquatic animals exist.
  • Moreover, it is possible to explain how the textual corruption occurred in the Nepalese version. A scribe, who did not follow the text or who was unfamiliar with the word okas as a final part of a compound, wrongly corrected what he saw as a scribal error in his exemplar from -aukasÄá¹ƒ to -aujasÄá¹ƒ. This scenario is especially probable if one considers the similarity between ja (ğ‘–) and ka (ğ‘) in some Nepalese scripts (see, for example, these characters in the Saddharmapuá¹‡á¸arÄ«ka ms. dated to 1082 and the MÅ«lamadhyamakakÄrikÄ ms. dated to 550-650).

As is the case with all emendations, there is no way to attain certainty, except by consulting new manuscript materials. However, one should keep in mind that in the course of the transmission from the earliest examples of SuÅ›rutaâ€™s to the Nepalese version, scribal errors will definitely have occurred, which will make minor amendments necessary here and there to reach a satisfactory text.

This is the case, for example, with MS Bikaner Anup 4391, that was reported in this way in NCC (New Catalogus Catalogorum, An Alphabetical Register of Sanskrit and Allied Works and Authors, 2015, pp. 7: 317). This led Meulenbeld to assert the existence of a manuscript of a commentary by Jejjaá¹­a on the SuÅ›rutasaá¹ƒhitÄ (Meulenbeld, 1999, pp. 1B 506 n.360). In fact, MS Bikaner Anup 4391 is the text of the SuÅ›rutasaá¹ƒhitÄ, with the Candraá¹­a verse in the colophon. It is likely that this is the same case for MS London IOLR Taylor 1842: this is currently being investigated, but which initially seems to be a manuscript supporting the SuÅ›rutasaá¹ƒhitÄ with the commentary of á¸Œalhaá¹‡a, but nothing by the author Candraá¹­a.

MSS currently known to have the so-called Candraá¹­a verse:

  • MS Bikaner Anup 4391
  • MS London IOLR Taylor 1842 (Eggeling catalogue 2646)
  • MS Kuruká¹£etra Jawaharlal Nehru Library 19786, f. 78v

Testimonia

There are also numerous statements in the secondary literature asserting that commentators cite Jejjaá¹­aâ€™s commentary on the SuÅ›rutasaá¹ƒhitÄ. For example, the NCC (idem) names HemÄdri, Vijayaraká¹£ita, á¹¬oá¸arÄnanda, NÄganÄtha, and RÅ«panayana, to which Meulenbeld added á¸Œalhaá¹‡a, GayadÄsa and NiÅ›calakara (ibid, v. 1A, p. 385). Some of these may indeed be concrete evidence for a commentary on the SuÅ›rutasaá¹ƒhitÄ by Jejjaá¹­a. They need to be studied individually, especially those of á¸Œalhaá¹‡a and NiÅ›calakara.

Induâ€™s commentary on the Aá¹£á¹­Äá¹…gasaá¹…graha

D. C. Bhattacharyya (Bhattacharyya, 1947, pp. 112, note 1) stated of RudrapÄraÅ›araâ€™s early edition of the Aá¹£á¹­Äá¹…gasaá¹…graha with the commentary ÅšaÅ›ilekhÄ by Indu (RudrapÄraÅ›ava, 1924), that,

The editor [RudrapÄraÅ›ara] had to rely on imperfect and fragmentary Mss. of the ÅšaÅ›ilekhÄ. But, â€¦ he filled up a lacuna in the ÅšaÅ›ilekhÄ with the text of the NirantarapadÄ« commentary (on SuÅ›ruta) by Jarjaá¹­a (vol. II, p. 298), which seems to be quite accessible to him, though it is a sealed book to the world outside. Many notes from Jarjaá¹­a [Jejjaá¹­a] have been printed in vols II and III.â€

The passage on p. 298 of RudrapÄraÅ›araâ€™s edition reads as follows:

à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥‹à¤£à¥‡à¤½à¤®à¥à¤­à¤¸ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¯à¤¾à¤°à¤­à¥à¤¯ à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¦à¤‚à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤°à¤•à¤•à¤·à¤¾à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¨à¥à¤¥à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¶à¤¶à¤¿à¤²à¥‡à¤–à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾ à¤…à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤œà¤°à¥à¤œà¤Ÿà¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¾ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤ªà¤¦à¥€ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤²à¤¿à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥‹à¤£à¥‡à¤½à¤®à¥à¤­à¤¸ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¨à¥€à¤¯à¥ˆà¤ƒ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤­à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¹à¤¾à¤•à¤·à¤¾à¤¯à¤¸à¤™à¥à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥ˆà¤°à¥ à¤¦à¤¶à¤­à¤¿à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤«à¤²à¥à¤—à¥à¤°à¥à¤—à¥‹à¤·à¥à¤ à¥‹à¤¦à¥à¤®à¥à¤¬à¤°à¤ƒ à¥¥ Because the *ÅšaÅ›ilekhÄ* is unavailable starting from the passage "à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥‹à¤£à¥‡à¤½à¤®à¥à¤­à¤¸" [As.ci.23.40] and ending with the passage "à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¦à¤‚à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤°à¤•à¤•à¤·à¤¾à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯" [As.ci.23.61], a commentary NirantarapadÄ«, composed by Jarjaá¹­a, is written. â€¦

This is an interesting passage, but both of Bhattacharyyaâ€™s assertions about it are probably wrong. One has to ask, â€œwhose voice is this commentarial statement?â€ It is impossible that Indu (fl. ca. 1000â€“1150) would have referred to his own commentary by name, saying that it was incomplete. It is also unlikely that it was RudrapÄraÅ›ara, in the 1920s. The passage is printed in the same size and font as the rest of the text of the ÅšaÅ›ilekhÄ. By contrast, p. 300 shows the typography of an editorial comment from RudrapÄraÅ›ara himself:

As we see, the text prints the editorâ€™s footnote to the text with an asterisk and a different font (p. 300, with two references to Jarjaá¹­a). Note, too, the reference to the Carakasaá¹ƒhitÄ (à¤šà¤°à¤•à¤ªà¤¾à¤ à¤ƒ).

As suggested by Deepro Chakraborty (personal communication), it is more likely that the passage printed in the book is what RudrapÄraÅ›ara saw in his source, namely the manuscript of Induâ€™s commentary. Therefore, the comment would be that of a scribe who produced the manuscript that RudrapÄraÅ›ara was reading. This would be a scribal insertion, perhaps from the margin of the archetype of RudrapÄraÅ›araâ€™s manuscript, responding to physical damage to the manuscript, that had migrated into the body of the main text during the next copying. This is a common feature of manuscript transmission. It may be possible to check this, if one can find the manuscript from which RudrapÄraÅ›ara was working.

Regarding Bhattacharyyaâ€™s second assertion, there is nothing in this passage to suggest that RudrapÄraÅ›ara had access to a commentary by Jejjaá¹­aâ€™s on the SuÅ›rutasaá¹ƒhitÄ On the contrary, the name NirantarapadÄ« is an abbreviation of the name of Jejjaá¹­aâ€™s commentary on the Carakasaá¹ƒhitÄ, i.e., â€œNirantarapadavyÄkhyÄâ€ (Zysk & Yamashita, 2019; Sastry & Pandey, 1975). Further, on p. 300 (above) there is an explicit reference to the version of the passage under discussion as it appears in the text of the Carakasaá¹ƒhitÄ (à¤šà¤°à¤•à¤ªà¤¾à¤ à¥‡).

entry.title: Textual Separative Differences
entry.content:
The project is starting to acquire a significant number of copies of manuscripts of the ÅšuÅ›rutasaá¹ƒhitÄ (SS). Currently (August 2025), we have manuscripts from Bikaner, Calcutta, Cambridge, Chandigarh, Delhi, Hyderabad, Jamnagar, Jodhpur, Kathmandu, Kurukshetra, Lahore, London, Lucknow and Pune. We donâ€™t have all the manuscripts from each of these places, and all the manuscripts are partial. But the archive is growing.

We need to develop techniques for triaging these manuscripts. That is to say, we are aware of a major cleavage in the history of transmission of the SS, between the Nepalese version and the vulgate. So when we look at a new manuscript, we want to have a rapid way of detecting whether it belongs to one or other of these transmissions, or to another transmission that is different from either.

The term â€œseparative errorâ€ is a term of art in textual criticism, also known as a Trennfehler. However, separative features of manuscripts need not be errors, but can be innovations or even more simply, differences. Thus, the expression â€œseparative innovationsâ€ is perhaps more appropriate (Acerbi, 2023, p. 2). What we are after in the present context are easily identifiable passages in a manuscript of the *SuÅ›rutasaá¹ƒhitÄ that will identify that manuscripts as belonging to one or other branch of the stemma. Since we are at present dealing with two branches, the vulgate and the Nepalese Version, â€œseparative differencesâ€ are passages that are clearly and definitely included or excluded in one or other version of the text.

At first, I thought the absence of the â€œyathovÄca bhagavÄn dhanvantariá¸¥â€ phrase would be a marker of the Nepalese version. But this is not the case. Manuscripts without this phrase still have vulgate readings. That suggests that the Dhanvantari phrase was added after the vulgate branch had already separated from the Nepalese transmission.
